author: ShankThatSnitch
body:
The DOT COM bubble also had companies like Intel, Sony, Cisco, Oracle, Qualcomm.....you know those fake companies that didn't make money. Well all of these companies either haven't gotten above the bubble price, or just recently did. So don't think just because there are legit companies, doesn't mean it can't get overvalued.

Also, there are a shitload of tech stocks right now that lose shitloads of money every year, and never make, or barely profit, yet still have massive valuations:

WORK, ZM, OKTA, CRWD, ZS, DOCU, MDB, DDOG, FSLY, UBER, LYFT, PINS, WDAY, SHOP, SPLK, TEAM, PANW.

That is not to say that these all won't make oodles of profit sometime in the future, but for now the prices of all of these have gotten out of control, just like it did for Sony, Cisco, Intel, Oracle...etc Everyone always points to the five biggest stocks are says "see these are not like the DOT COM stock", yet conveniently ignore the bloodbath of 1000 other stocks. Survivor bias.

TLDR: Buy calls on all tech, but be rdy to get booty fucked at some point. So take profits and withdraw cash from time to time to protect yourself from yourself.

author: swiggletraks
body:
Here are the three main things I have discovered from my own trading over the last couple of years:

1) Liquidity is KING! This is important because the bid-ask spread will eat away at profits faster than you can imagine, especially when things aren't going your way. Moreover, the less liquid that options are means the less reliable the probabilities and greeks are as well (as they are derived from option pricing). 

2) Trade ETFs as much as possible. I know at times they can look really unattractive with low premiums and even high BPR compared to individual equities but everything is priced for a reason. The equities are priced as they are because of the risk specific to the companies themselves that can lead to exceptional gains/losses (e.g., QCOM beginning of 2019). Unless we are able to construct our own portfolio of 30+ underlyings, we are going to be greatly exposed to the idiosyncratic risk of individual equities (not to mention individual stocks are usually not as liquid and have less reliable probabilities). If I do any equity options now, I make sure they are defined or that I'm willing to lose the 20% of money required for undefined risk trades. 

3) Trade small and often. For example, let's say I have a $100K account and I'm only willing to put 2% of my money into any one trade. This doesn't mean I have to do that though. I prefer to look at placing trades at a consistent contract size and making sure it doesn't exceed 2%. That means I may only have to put up $1k per trade or maybe only a couple hundred dollars. I can come back the next day and place another trade (maybe even the same trade). By doing this, I can be more nimble with the market and even choose to place different strategies (another form of diversification). Basically, the more often you are able to trade, the more you can cost average and smooth out all the greeks (e.g., volatility averaging).

I think there are a lot of benefits to trading options (e.g., learning to take calculated risk, make quicker decisions, keep a pulse on the market, etc.); however, I also think passive investing has a tremendous amount of opportunities as well (e.g., long-term capital gains, loss-harvesting, company retirement matching, scalability, etc.). It probably makes sense to have a portfolio that is constructed with both individual stocks and options.

This is what has worked best for me; however, remember that none of us know as much as we think we do, so take everything with a grain of salt and try it out small. Hope that helps!

author: p_giggles
body: TXN and TSMC are vastly different companies. TXN is a diversified semiconductor manufacturer which designs its own products and fabricates the majority of them internally, as opposed to fabless semi companies like Qualcomm, Broadcom, or Nvidia. These fabless companies design their own products and have them manufactured by a foundry like Taiwan Semi, which doesn't design anything.

author: TheIndulgery
Recoil42
body:
Tesla does actually *design* their own semiconductors, as was the case with HW3.

They don't *manufacture* their chips, but then, neither do Qualcomm or AMD or any number of others. That's par for course in the industry.

All of that is mostly inconsequential here though, because what's important isn't the chip design, but rather the board design, which Tesla definitely does do in-house, and is primarily what they're usually referred to as being *way ahead* on in the context of teardowns.

author: _metoo_x_x
body:
Watch the market everyday throughout the day.

If you’re testing out the market and afraid Buy the stock outright. Assuming you believe in the underlying potential of the company.

Then buy a call option that supports your optimism about a stock that you’ve “researched”.

I use the term research very loosely.

Ride the hype. But you only catch the beginning of the hype if you stay plugged into the meme cycle/news.

Good luck. Im mostly here for lulz but I’ve made some money on options. Most recent from QCOM.

Get some ERIC 2021/2022 $12 calls for a safe bet. Try to wait for a red day if you want to be cheap.
5G is coming whether people want it or not.

Personally, I buy the dip in big names stocks (calls that is)

Edit: comparing yourself to others will only give you unrealistic expectations. FOMO is a portfolio killer

author: undecidedmarketmaker
body:
[https://www.wsj.com/articles/ford-should-go-private-to-have-a-shot-at-lapping-tesla-11596813153?mod=hp\_lista\_pos3](https://www.wsj.com/articles/ford-should-go-private-to-have-a-shot-at-lapping-tesla-11596813153?mod=hp_lista_pos3) 

This means that someone big (probably Ford himself) reached out to a reporter to get this story out and gauge reactions. Personally, I'm *extremely* doubtful this is going to happen, the least reason being that I've met Ford several times and who did he remind me of? Paul Jacobs and XCOM. Long story short, few years ago Jacobs came up with a harebrained idea to take QCOM private. He was basically laughed out and ejected from his chairman spot. 

This is the *exact* same setup - family scion thinks he can pull off the heist of the decade while actual investors laugh their asses off.

tl;dr F $4P Jan 2021

author: FreeSpiritRunning
body:
The dotcom crash didn't happen in a day...it took a year and if you were just riding the wave and DCA'ing through 2000 you would have been down 20-30% on one year of investment before you said "Yeah fuck this I'm gonna bail to gold/real estate/cash" at the end of 2000. 

Compare that to the 5 year 300%+ run-up of the NASDAQ from 1995-2000 (which you would have kept if you had bailed in 2000) and you can see why trying to time the bubble is a bad idea. There could potentially be a lot more runup if/when it goes pop.

Also, I was in the market back then...there was A TON of warning from the FED. They seriously gave like a 2 month lead to the intrest rate hike...so its not like everyone just woke up on Monday and blew their coffee into the morning newspaper.

Was there FOMO? Hell yes, and a ton of denial. But people who were playing the market did fine...the guys that lost there asses were the dudes that YOLO'd their live savings into Pets.com and then took out a third mortgage on their house to get a little QCOM on the side.

As long as you aren't doing something like that right now I honestly wouldn't sweat it yet, theres zero indication that anything is going to turn the market. FAAMG just smashed earning in a quarter where the entire globe was shut down. Microsoft is trying to buy TikTok, Facebook just partnered with SHOP, SHOP just partnered with Walmart, Google just bought a stake in ADT, Amazon probably absorbed 15 more companies on the downlow between breakfast and lunch. Does this look like a struggling sector to you?

author: romxii
body:
Since P/E ratios are fucked and some companies are running at a deficit, you can look at Price to Sales TTM (trailing twelve month).

When comparing P/S ratio, try to use comparable companies in similar industries/sectors, geographies, margins, etc. 

If a company does many things, like a conglomerate or say Amazon, it becomes more art than a science.

&#x200B;

Do note that ratios aren't perfect since companies have different capital structures, margins, CAPEX/working capital requirements, and tax treatments.

&#x200B;

SQ is has a price to sales of 10.6 , not outrageous for a tech/fintech/payments company (MSFT and FB are at 11 and 10 respectively, V and MA at 19 and 20 respectively, PYPL at 11.9) 

TSLA is at 13 ish price to sales, in comparison Toyota is at a whopping 0.7, GM at 0.3, F at 0.2, Daimler at 0.3, VWAGY at 0.36. 

ZM at 87, the most retarded ratio of all.

AMD at 13. INTC is at 2.65, NVDA at 24.43, MU at 2.54, AVGO at 4.1, QCOM at 2.39, MCHP at 4.91.

Shopify at 58, second in retard strength only to ZM. EBAY is at 3.76, AMZN at 4.97. 

AAPL at 7.3

Amazon is at 4.98. Amazon touches multiple sectors and is a monster/star company, yet still doesnt hit TSLA's multiple, make of it what you want.

&#x200B;

SPCE, the king of all retards, with a ratio of 5122.

Yes I am aware valuations are about future value etc, enjoy your 5000+ P/S ratio.

body:
Autonomous driving but along with it...5g interco nnectivity, IoT. Qualcomm is my bet, but I'm sure there are many companies that will manufacture the capability for cars to communicate with maps, the cloud, other cars, the roads, and the cities they drive through. 

My obscure choice is rare diseases. Think SGMO, QURE, BLUE. Small cap biotech companies with high risk, high reward. They are becoming increasingly effective at not treating but actually curing obscure diseases. In another couple years the various varieties of hemophilia and sickle cell disease will be cured for a price. Think of when they crack the complex case that is neurophysiologic disorders: MS, ALS. 

And of course VR porn. /s

author: radarbot
body:
The only thing that makes me wary is that QCOM historical performance over the past 5 years has been really middling. Its almost as if its a swing stock, not an all-time-winner.

Its hard to judge if QCOM has it to be a real long term winner. Investing in it 5 years ago, or even 10 years ago, in a set and forget style strategy would have yielded very middling returns.

But if you look at the recent spread, it had a golden cross on June 25, which is not too long ago. So you have time to still catch the wave before it starts to tip back down.

Imo not that big of news, since Exynos chipsets are got garbage due to the power inneficent CPU cores, noone seemed to care that much about the GPU.

author: Pijoto
body: \*shrug\*  Seagate gets like 90% of their revenue from low margin and declining HDD sales, while HDDs account for only around half of WDC's revenue, and their SSD market keeps growing with more potential upside with the new console generation driving more demand for high speed NVME drives.  If WDC stock does drop, I don't see it being anywhere near severe as Seagate...so, I'm willing to take that bet on a potential pop in prices.

author: Rhaximus
body:
MU is better than ever and an undervalued company. Its problem is they pretty much only make DRAM, which is a very low profit business, and additionally have a huge amount of trendy competition from companies like Samsung, TSM, AMD, NVDA, Seagate, SanDisk, etc.

Big money allocates sector money selectively and MU doesn't make the cut anymore.

author: YoYo_Da
body: Seagate totally missed EPS by a ton on the 28th, crashed after. That should've been a heads-up for WD. If I had to guess, demand for physical storage (at least on the retail side if not enterprise) is likely down right now in comparison to cloud storage, which I'd guess is up for both retail and enterprise consumers.

author: Grunblau
body:
Picking up the shattered pieces of my WDC AH...  

I expect everyone to eventually realize that there are only two major players in the HDD space (Seagate and Western Digital) and only one of them that is heavily into NAND because of its ownership of SanDisk.  Long term hold, I guess.

author: the_river_nihil
body:
So, regarding airlines: you’re right to think “this industry is distressed right now, I should buy it to earn on the recovery”, that is a logical thought. However, airlines are taking on an *insane* amount of debt to weather this storm. They’re straight up burning *tens of millions a day* to keep what travel is allowed available. Airlines are getting hit even harder than casinos right now, and that recovery will take a very, very long time.

But, if you step that logic back a couple steps into something more fundamental it avoids a lot of those issues. No, I’m not talking Boeing (that will be shorter but still extremely subdued), I’m talking about Amphenol. They’re an electronics manufacturer that makes aerospace-grade parts. The further you get away from consumer habits, the wider timeframe these profits and losses operate in, and (right now at least) the more attractive that makes an investment.

People aren’t flying, companies aren’t going to be replacing planes any time soon either, but there’s foundational companies that are already up and running in anticipation of that. Because that’s *their* business cycle. Same goes for other industrial companies, like Air Products, or raw materials manufacturers on the DOW.

Don’t play this recovery at the consumer level, whatever you do. Play it at the manufacturing level, and play it as diversely as you can.

author: Cicero1982
body: I’m happier than a tornado in a trailer park! I picked out some value growth stocks last night, assessed the value I wanted to enter, and set my alerts. About an hour after market opened my alerts all blew up. I bought in on many, averaged down on a few, and ended today green. I have $12,000 allocated to averaging down on current positions if necessary and nearly 1/3rd of my portfolio available for new positions. Today was awesome! I now own SUM, CTXS, NET, IMOS, SIMO, & IVC. Even took a small position of DFFN for a short squeeze and very small position in BKYI because ... well ... freaking because!

author: totsnotbiased
body:
The first thing I would do is double your interest in every ETF/ actively managed funds you own outside the S&P 500, and sell the small positions you have in low growth companies like J&J, JPM, KO, CTXS. 

A good rule of thumb for you might be if you can’t see a world where the stock could double in the next 12-24 months, you shouldn’t hold less than .5% of your total portfolio in it.

You’re highly diversified, but that’s what ETF’s are for, and they are probably better at it than any of us
